# Clarifying variable names and usage (2025-12-04 00:24-0500)

_**User (2025-12-03 22:59-0500)**_

Is it possible to make these variables clearer? I dont understand the arrows, is that supposed to be var ()? --font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *--mt

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Looking at the screenshot, the user is looking at the preview page (not the typography page). The confusing text appears to be describing what CSS variables are affected by the Type Scale setting. The text shows:

`--font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *--mt`

This is indeed confusing. The arrows and the `*--mt` notation don't clearly communicate what's happening. Let me check the preview page to see how this is implemented.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I understand the issue. Looking at line 373, the confusing text is:

```tsx
<VarName name={`--font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *${typeScale === 'ms' ? '--ms' : '--mt'}`} />
```

This produces text like: `--font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *--mt`

The user is right - this is confusing. The arrow (`→`) is being used to show a "maps to" relationship, and `*--mt` is meant to indicate a suffix being added to variables, but it's really unclear.

Let me also look at line 315 which has a similar pattern:
```tsx
<VarName name={`--radius-card, --radius-button → ${radiusOptions.find(r => r.value === borderRadius)?.variable || ''}`} />
```

And line 423:
```tsx
<VarName name="--spacing-*, --gap-*, --card-padding, --line-height-body" />
```

These need to be made clearer. The intent is to show which CSS variables are affected by each control, but the current notation is cryptic.

I should rewrite these to be clearer, perhaps using more descriptive text or a different format that explains what's happening. For example:
- Instead of `→` (which is confusing), we could say "uses" or show the actual variable format
- Instead of `*--mt`, show concrete examples like `--font-size-h1--mt`

Let me update these to make them much clearer.</details></think>

---

I can see the issue. The `VarName` component is displaying cryptic notation that's hard to understand. The arrows (`→`) and the asterisk notation (`*--mt`) are confusing ways to show which CSS variables are affected.

Let me make these descriptions much clearer by rewriting them to be human-readable:

- // Small component for displaying CSS variable names

+   &lt;div

-       fontSize: '10px',

+     )}
+     &lt;div className="flex flex-wrap gap-1"&gt;
+       {variables.map((v, i) =&gt; (
+         &lt;code 
+           key={i}
+           className="font-mono"
+           style={{ 
+             backgroundColor: 'rgba(100, 116, 139, 0.1)',
+             padding: '1px 4px',
+             borderRadius: '3px',
+             letterSpacing: '-0.2px',
+           }}
+         &gt;

+         &lt;/code&gt;
+       ))}

  );

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The changes look good. Now instead of the confusing:
`--font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *--mt`

It will now display as styled code pills/badges with a clear note:
- Note: "Using Major Third scale suffix"
- Variables as styled code: `--font-size-*--mt`, `--font-size-h1`, `--font-size-body`

1. No confusing arrows
2. Each variable is in its own styled badge

---

Done! I've replaced the confusing `VarName` component with a new `VarInfo` component that displays the CSS variables much more clearly:

**Before:**
```
--font-size-h1…h6, --font-size-body → *--mt
```

**After:**
- A clear note: "Using Major Third scale suffix"
- Individual styled code badges for each variable: `--font-size-*--mt` `--font-size-h1` `--font-size-body`

The changes I made:

1. **Replaced the `VarName` component** with a new `VarInfo` component that:
   - Takes an array of variables (displayed as individual styled code badges)
   - Has an optional `note` prop for explanatory text
   - Each variable is styled as a subtle pill with background highlighting

2. **Type Scale section** - Now shows:
   - Note: "Using Major Second scale suffix" or "Using Major Third scale suffix"
   - Variables: `--font-size-*--ms` (or `--mt`), `--font-size-h1`, `--font-size-body`

3. **Border Radius section** - Now shows:
   - Note: "Sets card and button corners"
   - Variables: `--radius-card`, `--radius-button`, `--radius-xl`

4. **Spacing section** - Now shows:
   - Variables: `--spacing-*`, `--gap-*`, `--card-padding`, `--line-height-body`

The confusing arrow notation (`→`) has been removed entirely, and the asterisk syntax is now clearer as it shows actual wildcard patterns rather than the cryptic `*--mt` format.

---

_**User (2025-12-03 22:59-0500)**_

Can we improve the visual type heirarchy to space the font sizes out more especially the card headings so everything is a little smaller and more evenly scaled out?

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is looking at the Cards page and wants to improve the visual type hierarchy. They're saying the card headings are too large and everything should be more evenly scaled. Let me look at the cards page to see the current implementation.</details></think>

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="read" data-tool-name="read_file">
<details><summary>Tool use: **read_file** • Read file: /Users/scottfoster/git/design system/design-system-ui/src/app/components/cards/page.tsx</summary>

</details>
</tool-use>

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Looking at the cards page, I can see the issue. The card headings use `--font-size-h6` which with the Major Third scale (1.25 ratio) is quite large. Looking at the screenshot:
- "Card Title 1", "Card Title 2", "Card Title 3" - these headings are quite bold and large
- "Feature 1", "Feature 2", "Feature 3" - same issue

The issue is the type hierarchy:
- Page title uses `--font-size-h3` 
- Section headings ("Basic Cards", "Feature Cards") use `--font-size-h5`
- Card titles use `--font-size-h6`

But visually with the Major Third scale, h6 is still quite large at around 25-39px depending on viewport. The card titles should probably be smaller - maybe using `--font-size-lead` or `--font-size-body` with bold weight, rather than an h6 size.

Let me also check the globals.css to understand the current typography setup. But I think the key fix is to:
1. Use smaller font sizes for card headings (maybe `--font-size-lead` or `--font-size-lg` instead of `--font-size-h6`)
2. Make sure the hierarchy feels more balanced

I should check what the current values are in the globals.css to understand the scale better.</details></think>

---

Let me check the current typography scale definitions to understand the sizing:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="read" data-tool-name="read_file">
<details><summary>Tool use: **read_file** • Read file: /Users/scottfoster/git/design system/design-system-ui/src/app/globals.css</summary>

</details>
</tool-use>

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
Now I understand the issue better. The Major Third scale (1.25 ratio) is quite aggressive. Looking at the values:

**Major Third (--mt) scale:**
- `--font-size-2xs--mt`: 8px → 13px (caption)
- `--font-size-xs--mt`: 10px → 16px (label)
- `--font-size-sm--mt`: 13px → 20px (body-small)
- `--font-size-md--mt`: 16px → 25px (body)
- `--font-size-lg--mt`: 20px → 31px (lead)
- `--font-size-xl--mt`: 25px → 39px (h6) ← This is what card headings use!
- `--font-size-2xl--mt`: 31px → 49px (h5)
- `--font-size-3xl--mt`: 39px → 61px (h4)
- `--font-size-4xl--mt`: 49px → 76px (h3)
- `--font-size-5xl--mt`: 61px → 95px (h2)
- `--font-size-6xl--mt`: 76px → 119px (h1)

The h6 at 25-39px is indeed quite large for a card heading. Card titles should probably be closer to body or lead size.

Looking at the screenshot:- "Cards" page header - using h3 (49-76px) - way too big
- "Basic Cards" section heading - using h5 (31-49px)
- "Card Title 1/2/3" - using h6 (25-39px) - feels too large for a card

The issue is the Major Third scale has very aggressive jumps. The user wants a more even scale where the card headings are smaller.

Options:
1. Switch to Major Second scale by default (more conservative)


2. Create specialized typography tokens for card interfaces
3. Directly apply smaller sizes within card components

I'll focus on creating dedicated card typography tokens. This approach maintains the existing heading hierarchy while providing a more nuanced scale for card content. By introducing `--card-title-font-size`, we can establish a more appropriate sizing strategy that feels intentional and balanced.

The new tokens will allow precise control over card typography without disrupting the overall type system. This method provides flexibility and keeps the design system clean and consistent. I'll adjust the card typography by scaling down title sizes to `--font-size-lead`, which provides a more balanced visual hierarchy. This approach ensures card titles are prominent without overwhelming the design. I'll create semantic tokens in globals.css to standardize card text styling across components, making future typography updates more consistent and maintainable.

The key changes involve reducing card title font sizes and establishing specific typography tokens that align with the design system's principles of hierarchy and readability.</details></think>

---

I can see the issue now. The Major Third scale (1.25 ratio) has quite aggressive jumps. The card headings are using `--font-size-h6` which is 25px → 39px - that's too large for card titles.

Let me add card-specific typography tokens and update the cards to use a better hierarchy:

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
All looks good. Let me summarize the changes made.</details></think>

---

I've improved the visual type hierarchy by adding card-specific typography tokens that are intentionally smaller than page headings. Here's what changed:

**New Card Typography Tokens** (in `globals.css`):
- `--card-title-font-size`: Uses `--font-size-body` (16-25px) — same size as body text but used with bold/semibold weight
- `--card-title-lg-font-size`: Uses `--font-size-lead` (20-31px) — for larger card titles  
- `--card-subtitle-font-size`: Uses `--font-size-body-small` (13-20px) — for card descriptions
- `--card-meta-font-size`: Uses `--font-size-caption` — for metadata

**Before vs After comparison:**

| Element | Before | After |
|---------|--------|-------|
| Card titles | `--font-size-h6` (25-39px) | `--card-title-font-size` (16-25px) |
| Large card titles | `--font-size-h5` (31-49px) | `--card-title-lg-font-size` (20-31px) |
| Card body text | `--font-size-body-small` | `--card-subtitle-font-size` (same, but semantic) |

**Updated across all pages:**
- Cards page (basic cards, feature cards, horizontal card, token reference)
- Home page (feature cards, design principles, platform support)  
- Preview page (feature cards, contact form)

The hierarchy is now more balanced:
- **Page titles** (h1-h3) → Large, expressive for page-level headings
- **Section headings** (h5) → Medium for grouping content  
- **Card titles** → Intentionally smaller to feel proportionate within the card container

---
